>do you mean there could be multiple invokers?

that's correct - functions have transient residency and in a distributed system, the same function may run on multiple nodes (even at the same time).

>  do you mean the volume mapping will be deferred for 50ms after the container created?

no, he means that after the function returns, the container is paused after a grace period (of 50ms but can be changed). This is an openwhisk feature to allow a burst of functions reusing a container to avoid additional container overhead.

This looks like a bug in the sls plugin. I can't transfer the issue. Try the `wsk` cli and you can get better responses and fetch the result from its activation id.

By default a deployment will not wait more than 60s for a response and converts a blocking request to an asynchronous one.
Closing as actionable - the action failed/threw an exception and aborted the container abruptly. Usually you can reproduce the errors locally and it will be easier.

Sorry @jambonrose - I hope you figured it out and apologize for not getting back to you. I meant that you can replace the certificates in the deployment with your own SSL certs and eliminate the problem.

Using the ansible deployment, you can pass:
```
-e"nginx_ssl_path=$SSLDIR" -e"nginx_ssl_server_cert=nl-fullchain.pem" -e"nginx_ssl_server_key=nl-server-key.pem" -e"whisk_api_localhost_name=nimbella-lite.com" 
```

for example where `nl-*` are the custom certs.

Additionally we now have a http based standalone stack which doesn't have the SSL issue.
We're not maintaining this image actively and I will propose removing it on the Apache dev list.

I am looking into KEP first.

# General about KEP

* They run a separate repo for KEP: https://github.com/kubernetes/enhancements
* PM SIG(Product Management Special Interest Group) is in charge of the repo.
  * [SIG List](https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/sig-list.md)
  * SIG is generally module-based, there are chairs for each SIG.
* There is [a simple guideline](https://github.com/kubernetes/enhancements#is-my-thing-an-enhancement) to differentiate enhancements with the others.
* Generally, enhancements require multiple releases to implement them and it is to track the status of them.
* A enhancement is filed in the repo once there is a consensus at least in one SIG.
* Enhancements are tracked by Github issues. And before creating an issue he is supposed to
  * Share the enhancement via mailing lists, community meetings, or issues in other repos.
  * (optionally) Implement a prototype
  * Identify people who agree to work with (This is because it requires approx. 9mo ~ 1 year to implement.)
  * Be ready to become a project manager for the enhancement.
* There are 3 stages, alpha, beta, stable.
* It is to keep a high standard of integrity and consistency throughout all systems, tests, documentation, and so on.
* They are using labels
  * `sig/foo`: To denote which module is related. (ex: /sig api)
  * `kind/feature`: To denote the issue should be tracked as an enhancement. (/kind feature)
  * `tracked/yes`: To denote the issue is actively tracked in the current milestone.
  * `tracked/no`: To denote the issue is not tracked in the current milestone.
  * `stage/{alpha,beta,stable}`: The stage of the enhancement.

They defined KEP using [KEP-1](https://github.com/kubernetes/enhancements/blob/master/keps/0001-kubernetes-enhancement-proposal-process.md). It includes the details about KEP.
There are also [a template](https://github.com/kubernetes/enhancements/blob/master/keps/YYYYMMDD-kep-template.md) for KEP.

From now on, I will look into KEP-1 and the template for the details.

I've found the reason. The [host metrics module](https://kamon.io/docs/latest/instrumentation/system/host-metrics/#available-metrics) was not explicitly disabled in the 2.x version. 

### Legacy configuration (1.x)
The following configuration is no longer supported. It should be removed

https://github.com/apache/openwhisk/blob/b26101b8dc0d7a2f48995cd81f12d5b2db10be46/common/scala/src/main/resources/application.conf#L84

```
    system-metrics {
        # disable the host metrics as we are only interested in JVM metrics
        host.enabled = false
    }
```

### Latest version configuration (2.0.x)

To disable host metrics in the latest version, below configuration should be added
```
kamon.modules {
  host-metrics {
    enabled = no
  }
}
```

#### Reference
https://kamon.io/docs/latest/instrumentation/system/host-metrics/#disabling-the-module

> What happens if I run java -jar openwhisk-standalone.jar without '--kafka' switch?

Then OpenWhisk runs in [lean mode][1] (#4216) without Kafka. With `--kafka` it uses [embedded kafka][2]. See #4628 for details on what all was done for this mode. Note that it uses Kafka 2.1.1. So basic stuff works as expected with this Kafka version.

To make standalone connect to existing running Kafka would need some work as current approach was implemented with embedded mode and has to adapt the listeners to workaround the Docker networking. May be try launching Standalone without `--kafka` switch and instead set following system properties

```
-Dwhisk-config.kafka.hosts=localhost:9093 -Dwhisk.spi.MessagingProvider=org.apache.openwhisk.connector.kafka.KafkaMessagingProvider
-Dwhisk.spi.LoadBalancerProvider=org.apache.openwhisk.standalone.KafkaAwareLeanBalancer
```

Change the port as per your setup. I have not tried it so cannot comment if it works as expected!

[1]: https://medium.com/openwhisk/lean-openwhisk-open-source-faas-for-edge-computing-fb823c6bbb9b
[2]: https://github.com/embeddedkafka/embedded-kafka
Moved bit further on this with #4783. Would now try to dig more details via [scalac profiling](https://www.scala-lang.org/blog/2018/06/04/scalac-profiling.html)

Note that some aspect like embedded Kafka support may not work as expected due to Docker networking. See #4628 and [kafka listeners explanation][1] for details. Which should be ok though as this mode (`--kafka`) would mostly be used by developers extending OpenWhisk and they would be better of using the java mode

[1]: https://rmoff.net/2018/08/02/kafka-listeners-explained/
It seems that in this mode upon starting openwhisk docker `docker stop openwhisk` the launched containers do not get removed. Have not dig further in the root cause

Considering that the OpenWhisk community is much smaller than Kubernetes I think a very lightweight process might be sufficient.

https://github.com/apache/cordova-discuss is one example of such a lightweight process: basically just a set of proposal documents in a single place, with state annotations like "incoming", "in progress", "completed", "abandoned" or something like that. Those annotations can be Markdown front matter or just a page which lists the proposals like in that example.

Just my 2 cents - I'm not actively involved in OpenWhisk development, but hopefully this helps.

In a simple initial version this might be something like:
* add a startTime and (configurable) TTL to prewarm containers in ContainerPool
* add a scheduled task to periodically delete unused prewarms that have passed TTL expiration
* add a configurable "prewarm scaleup step" where if a cold start container matches a prewarm config AND no prewarm was available AND the prewarm count for that config is below the runtime manifest config then launch up to "prewarm scaleup step" prewarms to replenish prewarms in case load has increased

In addition, startup behavior may be worth changing as well (to avoid starting a bunch of prewarms, just to delete them on TTL), by changing the manifest to use "initCount" and "maxCount" instead of "count" - to set an invoker startup config, and a cap on number of prewarm containers that are allowed over time.

I think it is ready for merging. I added:
- documentation
- a start.sh script that also open the playground 
- the start script can be shortened to https://s.apache.org/openwhisk.sh (to do after merging)
- tested the start.sh script in osx, linux, windows 
- a stop script that also cleans the other images created
- also CORS support for the playground as I was having problems with CORS running it locally.
WIP can be removed from this it seems ready to go.
